title: Chapter 11 Nervous System (Class Outline Pack)
notes: MBLEx-style: single-best-answer, parallel distractors (avoid length cues), OIA not included, no sense organs. Explanations are Why/Trap/Hook. Schema: mcq/reverse choices are {A,B,C,D}; correct_choice is one of A/B/C/D.

questions.prompt: Which option best matches the three main roles of the nervous system?

explanation.why: The nervous system detects changes, processes information, and triggers responses.
explanation.trap: Other body systems have different core roles that sound scientific but don’t fit.

questions.prompt: Which structures make up the central nervous system (CNS)?

explanation.why: CNS refers specifically to brain + spinal cord; nerves/ganglia are PNS.
explanation.trap: Cranial and spinal nerves feel “central” but they’re peripheral.

questions.prompt: A neuron that carries information from a receptor toward the CNS is a(n):

explanation.why: Afferent (sensory) neurons bring signals into the CNS.
explanation.trap: Efferent neurons go out to effectors, not in from receptors.

questions.prompt: A neuron that carries commands from the CNS to a muscle is a(n):

explanation.why: Efferent (motor) neurons carry signals from CNS to muscles or glands.
explanation.trap: Afferent is sensory input; efferent is motor output.

questions.prompt:
Term: Neuroglia
Which description BEST fits?

explanation.why: Neuroglia are support cells that protect and assist neurons.
explanation.trap: Neurons conduct signals; glia support the environment.

questions.prompt:
Term: Ependymal cells
Which description BEST fits?

choices.A: Line ventricles and help move cerebrospinal fluid
choices.B: Form myelin in the peripheral nervous system
choices.D: Form the blood–brain barrier around capillaries

explanation.why: Ependymal cells line ventricles and contribute to CSF movement/production.
explanation.trap: Astrocytes relate to BBB; Schwann relates to PNS myelin.

questions.prompt: The resting electrical charge difference across a neuron’s membrane is the __________ potential.

explanation.why: The resting potential is the baseline membrane charge difference.
explanation.trap: Don’t confuse resting potential with action potential phases.

questions.prompt: During depolarization, which ion moves into the neuron through voltage-gated channels?

explanation.why: Na+ influx makes the inside less negative, initiating depolarization.
explanation.trap: K+ is mainly tied to repolarization, not the initial depolarization.

questions.prompt: Repolarization is MOST directly associated with:

explanation.why: K+ efflux returns the membrane toward its resting state.
explanation.trap: Na+ influx is the classic depolarization driver.

questions.prompt: The brief time when a neuron cannot fire another action potential is the __________ period.

explanation.why: In the absolute refractory period, the neuron cannot fire regardless of stimulus strength.
explanation.trap: Refractory isn’t “resting”; it’s a firing limitation window.

questions.prompt: Which term describes a collection of neuron cell bodies in the PNS?

explanation.why: In the PNS, cell bodies cluster in ganglia; in CNS they form nuclei/gray matter.
explanation.trap: Tracts/fascicles are bundles of axons, not cell bodies.

questions.prompt: How many pairs of spinal nerves are typically described in basic anatomy?

explanation.why: A standard count is 31 pairs of spinal nerves.
explanation.trap: 12 pairs is the classic cranial nerve count.

questions.prompt:
Term: Dermatome
Which description BEST fits?

choices.A: Skin region supplied by sensory fibers from a spinal nerve
choices.B: Muscle group supplied by a spinal nerve motor root
choices.C: Bone region supplied by a named artery
choices.D: Joint capsule supplied by a ligament

explanation.why: Dermatomes map skin sensation regions to spinal nerves.
explanation.trap: Myotomes relate to muscle action patterns, not skin.

questions.prompt: Which brain region includes the midbrain, pons, and medulla oblongata?

explanation.why: Brainstem = midbrain + pons + medulla oblongata.
explanation.trap: Diencephalon includes thalamus/hypothalamus, not pons/medulla.

questions.prompt:
Term: Cerebellum
Which description BEST fits?

choices.B: Relays all sensory input to cortex

explanation.why: The cerebellum helps coordinate movement, posture, and balance.
explanation.trap: Thalamus is the classic sensory relay, not cerebellum.

questions.prompt: Which division of the nervous system most directly controls voluntary skeletal muscle?

explanation.why: Somatic motor control is voluntary control of skeletal muscle.
explanation.trap: Autonomic targets smooth/cardiac muscle and glands.

questions.prompt: Which pairing BEST matches division and typical target?

explanation.why: ANS output targets smooth muscle, cardiac muscle, and glands.
explanation.trap: Somatic output is skeletal muscle control.

questions.prompt:
Term: Sympathetic division
Which description BEST fits?

choices.D: Carries sensation from skin to CNS

explanation.why: Sympathetic activation supports readiness and mobilization.
explanation.trap: Parasympathetic is the classic rest-and-digest partner.

questions.prompt:
Term: Parasympathetic division
Which description BEST fits?

explanation.why: Parasympathetic activation supports restoration and digestion.
explanation.trap: Sympathetic is the classic fight-or-flight partner.

questions.prompt: Which statement is MOST accurate about a neurotransmitter’s effect on a target organ?

choices.A: Receptor type on the target tissue shapes the response
choices.B: A neurotransmitter always produces one fixed response
choices.C: Only the CNS can change neurotransmitter effects
choices.D: Targets respond only if myelin is present

explanation.why: The same neurotransmitter can produce different effects depending on receptor type.
explanation.trap: Assuming one transmitter = one effect ignores receptor specificity.

questions.prompt: A bundle of axons in the CNS is called a __________.

explanation.why: In the CNS, axon bundles are tracts; in the PNS they’re nerves.
explanation.trap: Calling everything a “nerve” blurs CNS vs PNS terms.

questions.prompt: A bundle of axons in the PNS is called a:

explanation.why: In the PNS, bundles of axons are nerves.
explanation.trap: Tracts are the CNS term for axon bundles.

questions.prompt:
Term: Gray matter
Which description BEST fits?

choices.A: Region rich in neuron cell bodies and synapses
choices.D: A protective layer around the brain

explanation.why: Gray matter contains many cell bodies, dendrites, and synapses.
explanation.trap: White matter is the classic myelinated-axon region.

questions.prompt:
Term: White matter
Which description BEST fits?

choices.B: Region rich in neuron cell bodies and synapses
choices.D: A cluster of PNS cell bodies

explanation.why: White matter contains many myelinated axons, giving it a lighter appearance.
explanation.trap: Gray matter is where many cell bodies and synapses are.

questions.prompt: Which description BEST fits an interneuron?

choices.A: Neuron that connects neurons within the CNS
choices.B: Neuron that carries sensory input into CNS
choices.C: Neuron that carries motor output to muscle

explanation.why: Interneurons link neurons and integrate signals, largely within the CNS.
explanation.trap: Afferent/efferent describe direction of information, not integration role.

questions.prompt: A postsynaptic potential is MOST directly influenced by:

choices.D: Red blood cell count in plasma

explanation.why: Synaptic signaling depends on transmitter binding to postsynaptic receptors.
explanation.trap: Myelin changes conduction speed, not receptor binding events.

questions.prompt: Which term best describes the electrical state when the inside of a neuron is more negative than the outside?

explanation.why: A resting neuron is polarized with a negative interior relative to exterior.
explanation.trap: Depolarization reduces that charge difference.

questions.prompt:
Term: Thalamus
Which description BEST fits?

choices.A: Major relay for sensory information to the cortex
choices.B: Primary coordinator of balance and posture

explanation.why: The thalamus is a key relay station for many sensory pathways to cortex.
explanation.trap: Cerebellum coordinates movement; thalamus relays inputs.

questions.prompt: Which term refers to a rapid, predictable response to a stimulus?

explanation.why: A reflex is a rapid, automatic response to a stimulus.
explanation.trap: Accommodation is a vision term, not a rapid motor response.

questions.prompt: The nervous system division that regulates smooth muscle, cardiac muscle, and glands is the __________ nervous system.

explanation.why: The autonomic nervous system regulates involuntary targets like glands and smooth/cardiac muscle.
explanation.trap: Somatic controls skeletal muscle, not glands.

questions.prompt: Which term describes the largest part of the brain responsible for higher thought and voluntary action?

explanation.why: The cerebrum supports higher cognition, perception, and voluntary motor control.
explanation.trap: Cerebellum is coordination; brainstem handles basic life functions.

questions.prompt: A client’s stimulus is detected by receptors and sent toward the CNS. Which pathway term BEST fits that direction?

explanation.why: Afferent describes signals traveling from receptors toward the CNS.
explanation.trap: Efferent is the outward motor pathway to effectors.

questions.prompt: Myelin primarily increases nerve signal speed by:

choices.A: Reducing ion leakage and enabling saltatory conduction
choices.B: Increasing synapse size for faster diffusion
choices.C: Making dendrites longer for better reception
choices.D: Adding more cell bodies to the nerve

explanation.why: Myelin insulates the axon and supports saltatory conduction between nodes.
explanation.trap: Synapse size is not the main driver of along-axon conduction speed.

questions.prompt: Which option BEST describes an action potential threshold?

choices.A: Membrane voltage that triggers rapid depolarization
choices.B: Time it takes for K+ to leave the neuron
choices.C: Maximum firing rate of a motor neuron
choices.D: Number of synapses in a pathway

explanation.why: Threshold is the membrane voltage that initiates the all-or-none action potential.
explanation.trap: Refractory timing and ion movement are related but not the definition of threshold.

questions.prompt: Which statement BEST describes the absolute refractory period?

choices.A: A time when the neuron cannot fire another action potential
choices.B: A time when the neuron fires repeatedly without stimulus
choices.C: A time when the neuron is more sensitive to stimulation
choices.D: A time when neurotransmitters cannot be released

explanation.why: During absolute refractory, voltage-gated Na+ channels cannot reset fast enough to fire again.
explanation.trap: Relative refractory is when firing is harder, not impossible.

questions.prompt:
Term: Oligodendrocytes
Which description BEST fits?

choices.A: Form myelin in the central nervous system
choices.B: Form myelin in the peripheral nervous system
choices.C: Line ventricles and move cerebrospinal fluid

explanation.why: Oligodendrocytes myelinate CNS axons; Schwann cells myelinate PNS axons.
explanation.trap: Swapping Schwann and oligodendrocyte roles is a common mix-up.

questions.prompt:
Term: Microglia
Which description BEST fits?

choices.A: Immune-like cells that perform phagocytosis in CNS
choices.B: Cells that line ventricles and move CSF
choices.C: Cells that form BBB around capillaries

explanation.why: Microglia act like macrophages in CNS tissue for cleanup and defense.
explanation.trap: Astrocytes relate to BBB, not primary phagocytosis role.

questions.prompt: Which pairing BEST matches structure with its primary function?

explanation.why: Dendrites typically receive signals; axons carry signals away from the soma.
explanation.trap: Axons send; dendrites receive—don’t swap the directions.

questions.prompt: In a reflex arc, which component usually carries signals from the CNS to the effector?

explanation.why: Efferent motor neurons carry the output from CNS to muscles or glands.
explanation.trap: Afferent neurons carry input from receptors into the CNS.

questions.prompt: Which term BEST describes a bundle of axons inside a peripheral nerve?

explanation.why: A fascicle is a bundle of axons within a nerve, wrapped by connective tissue layers.
explanation.trap: Ganglion refers to cell bodies, not bundled axons.

questions.prompt: Which pairing BEST matches term and location?

explanation.why: In the CNS, clusters of cell bodies are nuclei; in the PNS they’re ganglia.
explanation.trap: Nerve is PNS; tract is CNS—don’t swap them.

questions.prompt: Which statement BEST describes saltatory conduction?

choices.A: Action potentials “jump” between nodes of Ranvier
choices.B: Action potentials travel only through dendrites
choices.D: Axons conduct only when muscles contract

explanation.why: Myelinated axons conduct by jumping between nodes, increasing speed.
explanation.trap: Saltatory conduction is along the axon, not across synapses.

questions.prompt: The rapid rise and fall of membrane voltage that travels along an axon is an __________ potential.

explanation.why: An action potential is the rapid electrical signal that propagates along an axon.
explanation.trap: Don’t confuse action potential with resting potential or threshold.

questions.prompt: Which option BEST distinguishes afferent from efferent pathways?

choices.A: Afferent brings input; efferent sends output
choices.B: Afferent sends output; efferent brings input
choices.C: Afferent controls glands; efferent controls skin
choices.D: Afferent is CNS only; efferent is PNS only

explanation.why: Afferent = sensory input toward CNS; efferent = motor output to effectors.
explanation.trap: Swapping directions is the classic test trap.

questions.prompt:
Term: Refractory period
Which description BEST fits?

choices.A: Time after an action potential when firing is limited

explanation.why: Refractory periods limit immediate re-firing as channels reset.
explanation.trap: Refractory is about firing readiness, not neurotransmitter storage.

questions.prompt: Which brain region BEST fits: thalamus + hypothalamus + epithalamus?

explanation.why: The diencephalon includes thalamus, hypothalamus, and epithalamus.
explanation.trap: Brainstem is midbrain/pons/medulla, not thalamus/hypothalamus.

questions.prompt: Which statement BEST describes sympathetic vs parasympathetic organization?

choices.A: They are divisions of the autonomic nervous system
choices.B: They are divisions of the somatic nervous system
choices.C: They are parts of the cerebellum
choices.D: They are types of sensory receptors

explanation.why: Sympathetic and parasympathetic are the two main ANS divisions in basic anatomy.
explanation.trap: Somatic is voluntary skeletal control, not these divisions.

questions.prompt: Which option BEST describes why myelinated axons conduct faster than unmyelinated axons?

choices.A: Myelin reduces membrane capacitance and ion leakage
choices.B: Myelin increases neurotransmitter release at synapses
choices.C: Myelin increases dendrite branching for reception
choices.D: Myelin increases the number of cell bodies in a nerve

explanation.why: Insulation reduces current loss and supports node-to-node conduction.
explanation.trap: Speed differences are primarily about axon conduction properties, not synapse release.

questions.prompt:
Term: Interneuron
Which description BEST fits?

choices.A: Neuron that links neurons and integrates signals in CNS
choices.B: Neuron that carries sensory input from skin to CNS
choices.C: Neuron that carries commands from CNS to muscle
choices.D: Cell that forms BBB around capillaries

explanation.why: Interneurons connect neurons and support integration within CNS circuits.
explanation.trap: Astrocytes relate to BBB; interneurons are neurons, not glia.

questions.prompt: A cluster of neuron cell bodies in the CNS is called a __________.

explanation.why: In the CNS, cell bodies cluster as nuclei; in the PNS they form ganglia.
explanation.trap: Ganglion is the PNS term, not the CNS term.

questions.prompt: Which pairing BEST matches a pathway and its destination?

choices.C: Afferent → gland only; efferent → skin only
choices.D: Afferent → cerebellum only; efferent → cortex only

explanation.why: Afferent signals go to CNS; efferent signals go to muscles or glands.
explanation.trap: Swapping destinations is the high-frequency confusion.

questions.prompt: A neuron is at -55 mV and reaches threshold. Which event sequence BEST matches the start of an action potential?

choices.A: Voltage-gated Na+ opens → Na+ enters → rapid depolarization
choices.B: Voltage-gated K+ opens → K+ enters → rapid depolarization
choices.C: Ligand-gated Cl- opens → Cl- exits → rapid depolarization
choices.D: Na+/K+ pump stops → Na+ exits → depolarization

explanation.why: Threshold triggers voltage-gated Na+ channels to open, driving depolarization.
explanation.trap: K+ opening is later for repolarization; pumps don’t create the spike sequence directly.

questions.prompt: A nerve fiber is cut. Which factor MOST limits regeneration in the CNS compared with the PNS?

choices.A: Lack of neurilemma support for regrowth
choices.B: Lack of any glial cells in CNS tissue
choices.C: Lack of sodium channels in CNS axons
choices.D: Lack of blood supply to CNS tissue

explanation.why: CNS lacks a neurilemma pathway that supports axon regrowth like in PNS.
explanation.trap: CNS has glia and sodium channels; the regrowth environment differs.

questions.prompt: Which option BEST explains why a stronger stimulus may be needed during the relative refractory period?

choices.A: Some Na+ channels have not fully reset, so depolarization is harder
choices.B: All Na+ channels are permanently closed after firing
choices.C: K+ channels are absent, so repolarization cannot occur
choices.D: Myelin dissolves briefly after each action potential

explanation.why: Relative refractory means firing is possible but requires a stronger stimulus as channels recover.
explanation.trap: Absolute refractory is “cannot fire”; relative refractory is “harder to fire.”

questions.prompt: Which pairing BEST distinguishes tract vs nerve vs fascicle vs ganglion?

choices.A: Tract: CNS axons; nerve: PNS axons; fascicle: bundle within nerve; ganglion: PNS cell bodies
choices.B: Tract: PNS axons; nerve: CNS axons; fascicle: CNS cell bodies; ganglion: CNS axons
choices.C: Tract: CNS cell bodies; nerve: PNS cell bodies; fascicle: synapse region; ganglion: CSF space
choices.D: Tract: skin receptors; nerve: muscle fibers; fascicle: bone bundle; ganglion: cartilage node

explanation.why: These terms differ by location and what they contain (axons vs cell bodies).
explanation.trap: Mixing “axon bundle” terms with “cell body cluster” terms is the common confusion.
explanation.hook: Axons vs bodies, CNS vs PNS.

questions.prompt:
Term: Blood–brain barrier (BBB)
Which description BEST fits?

choices.A: A barrier that restricts many substances from leaving capillaries into CNS tissue
choices.B: A membrane that carries action potentials down an axon
choices.C: A structure that produces cerebrospinal fluid in ventricles
choices.D: A sheath that wraps PNS axons to speed conduction

explanation.why: BBB limits many substances from entering CNS tissue from the bloodstream.
explanation.trap: Myelin speeds conduction; BBB controls exchange at capillaries.

questions.prompt:
Term: Saltatory conduction
Which description BEST fits?

choices.A: Conduction that jumps between nodes on a myelinated axon
choices.B: Conduction that diffuses neurotransmitter across a synapse
choices.C: Conduction that moves only along dendrites
choices.D: Conduction that occurs only in unmyelinated fibers

explanation.why: Saltatory conduction is node-to-node jumping on myelinated axons.
explanation.trap: Synaptic diffusion is a different process than along-axon conduction.

questions.prompt:
Term: Absolute refractory period
Which description BEST fits?

choices.A: Time when a neuron cannot fire another action potential
choices.B: Time when a stronger stimulus is needed to fire
choices.C: Time when neurotransmitter is released repeatedly
choices.D: Time when myelin is rebuilt after firing

explanation.why: Absolute refractory is a no-fire window as Na+ channels reset.
explanation.trap: Relative refractory is “harder,” not “impossible.”

questions.prompt: The voltage at which an action potential is triggered is the __________.

explanation.why: Threshold is the trigger voltage that initiates the all-or-none spike.
explanation.trap: Refractory and resting are different concepts than threshold.

questions.prompt: In saltatory conduction, action potentials propagate between nodes of __________.

explanation.why: Nodes of Ranvier are the gaps in myelin where the signal “jumps.”
explanation.trap: Don’t confuse nodes with ganglia (cell bodies).
